parent.body: Not by me, I agree. I think people who insist that C and C++ are two *completely different languages* are taking it too far. The only thing that I miss in C are exceptions, I hate to test the return value of nearly every call, I want to focus on why I write the code in the first place. That quite explains why I've been a happy pythonista for over a decade now and don't plan to switch any time soon. Quite the opposite, in fact, as python expands and gets into microcontrollers, web development etc. The day when it replaces JS in browser will be the happiest day of my life.

post.body:
I am not even close to a good developer, and C++ is my main language. It is not difficult. The transition from Java to C++ was easy and I'm not seeing what's "so hard to understand" about C++. Actually I think it's much easier to use than a lot of the so-called "beginner" languages such as *JavaScript*, which you pretty much have to be a fucking expert in to do even the simplest things >:(. But most people think C/C++ are so hard that they're afraid of them, and that they are to be avoided if at all possible! While the latter has a large standard library, on their own they're both fairly straightforward and self-explanatory languages, not unlike Java, C#, or Python, in fact they have less layers of abstraction than those which usually makes them even less complicated. I don't see what's so hard about that. What part of C/C++ is so difficult compared to other languages?

Of course I'm not saying you should always use C/C++ for everything when certain things can indeed be done better in another language. Sometimes the extra functionality of higher level languages is very useful. But I don't see how that makes C/C++ *hard*, just not the proper choice for everything as is the case with all languages.

body: I usually don't use double pointers if possible. If I need a multi-dimensional array I just make a pointer to the first element of the first array, and split the allocated memory accordingly. It's usually more contiguous that way anyways.

parent.body: I agree but I've also been bitten by my mistakes related to memory management, such as when I forgot to initialize a variable and it happened to have whatever value was in that memory at the time, or fixing memory leaks in my code running on university cluster etc. One needs to have a decent understanding of what goes on memory-wise to be able to not fall into these traps, and that tends to be an issue for beginners who don't have that understanding and experience yet.

parent.body:
Also, this is less of a problem nowadays, but many old hands remember it being a *nightmare* just getting the environment set up before even reaching to hello world. I remember being taught on a proprietary compiler, and then having to re-teach myself at home because I was using different tools. I ended up doing my C++ projects at the school labs because the hassle of porting work back and forth wasn't worth it.

It's not a fair critique on the language, and the development tools and libraries have gotten much better and more standardized, but I think a lot of the negativity around the languages comes from people remembering this era, and even today it's a far cry from `sudo apt install python3`

body: I'm about to get crucified for saying this, but C++ is really just a superset of C. It's basically the same as C but it can do a lot more of that stuff for you "out of the box". That's the main reason I usually prefer it over C, otherwise I wouldn't because C isn't as annoying with stuff like type casts, is even more predictable and straightforward, and has native support for `restrict` (even though I'm like the only one on the planet who even uses it).

body:
> Rvalues

I've seen that term about once or twice ever. Can't say I've ever used or needed it for anything. I think you're over-complicating things.

>  use the language for a month now

You're probably not going to have a solid understanding of any language after a month. Unless you spend every second learning it, it's going to take time to get a firm grasp.

> Cmake makes me want to punch my monitor as well.

Haha I don't know how to use CMake either :D. CMake is not easy to understand and there are about zero resources to learn it, so you're either lucky enough to know it already or you don't. But it's not part of C/C++, it's a build script and I think it can cause more trouble than its worth. Unless you're doing some hugely popular project, specifying commands for the popular compilers is probably enough and will actually be less buggy too.

> Template code can get very 'creative' as well

It's hard because you rarely use it. Unless you're making a library it's generally not something that comes up often in my experience.

body:
I don't see how it sucks any more than other languages (JS sucks a ton on its own, but that's an exception). I actually like how it's not restrictive and you can do a lot of things that make perfect sense but other languages don't let you. I also like how you have access to the actual machine as opposed to being locked into an interpreter or VM for another piece of software, though that's definitely not necessary for a lot of programs. Basically, it feels like there's not much you can't do in it, whereas in a good bit of other languages there's a lot of things you can't do. Certain things may be easier or more highly optimized for other languages, and in that case it makes sense (ofc reddit and ruqqus aren't written in C++, python/C#/PHP are much better suited for webdev). But I don't see how that makes C/C++ suck.

> If you want cross platform compatibility, there are obviously better choices.

Not necessarily. Most libraries these days are already cross-platform, so there's only a few edge cases where you need to use platform-specific code. In that case you just do a few if/else macros and you're good.

> It's tedious. It's finicky.

You're describing JavaScript.

> The syntax looks nasty.

It takes a while to get used to if you're not using it already, but it's fine. Personally the only one I've seen that actually has good syntax on its own is python. Everything else takes a good bit of getting used to.

> You have to spend more time being concerned with low level security

What do you mean by "low level security"?

parent.body:
I don't encounter people that think C and C++ are hard. Instead I encounter people that think C++ just sucks and I agree entirely.

Obviously that is a subjective opinion and it "sucking" has everything to do with what it's being used for.

If the project is small and/or has no explicit need to be absolutely efficient, the cons of using C++ outweigh the pros in my opinion. If you want cross platform compatibility, there are obviously better choices.

It's tedious. It's finicky. The syntax looks nasty. You have to spend more time being concerned with low level security. Don't even get me started on header files (and before you berate me, I understand why they're useful, I just can't stand them).

I know I didn't really answer your question, but I really don't hear people saying that it's hard necessarily.

body: I don't think you need to look for excuses to use every single feature of a language. The STL is huge, and I've never used the mast majority of it either. It comes in handy sometimes to avoid having to write my own implementation of something, but I certainly don't know everything it has to offer. I still use arrays, pointers, chars, and malloc for example, and even though some people will scream bloody murder at me for it the fact is if there's no good reason to use STL for something, then don't. You don't have to learn the entire STL to use it effectively, that's actually counter-productive. And even if you did, C++ can still be used without the STL and only the C stdlib.

Of course I'm not saying you should always use C/C++ for everything when certain things can indeed be done better in another language. Sometimes the extra functionality of higher level languages is very useful. But I don't see how that makes C/C++ *hard*, just not the proper choice for everything as is the case with all languages.

post.body:
Fanmade C++ api, C++17 or higher only.

If wanting to compile, you need:

libcurlpp4-dev
libjsoncpp-dev
pthread

That's basically all :)

*What this API has?*

* very nice method to update tokens (no more token renewals every hour :D)
* very flexible
* you can set cookies for API endpoints that require it.
* the underlying http engine on curlpp can be used for almost any API (obtaining XKCD comics?)
* relatively small (less than 1,000 lines of code)
* fast

*What this API dosen't has?*

* thread-safety (some functions)
* testing (i.e most administrative functions, the CSAM nuke, etc)

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
I doubt it. For example ruqqus-plus is behind even ruqqyou and it's a much larger project that probably gets quite a bit of attention (from ruqqus, it's not lucky enough to be visible from github itself). But ruqqJS is a 3-commit project that doesn't even do anything yet and was placed at the very top immediately. I would say the download count and views and stars and such are the *consequence* of where it appears in search, not the cause.

Looking at the history of the repos, it looks like where it appears in the search results has more to do with who you are than anything else. I've noticed that the same people always get the same patterns of traffic and positions in search results for all their repos. How this is determined I have no idea, but it seems like that's how it's working. On reddit, I made the front page a few times and after that all my posts were always more visible than before and reaching the front page was easier. Then I changed accounts and it became harder again. I wouldn't doubt that github is doing something similar.

I have a small problem where github is not letting anyone discover any of my repositories naturally. Most people I see get about 10-20 downloads per repo on average after a month or two, and get a small amount of traffic each day. This is typically done without any promotional efforts, so basically through the github algorithm and people discovering it through searching and exploring.

However, only one person other than me has ever downloaded something of mine, and according to the insights I'm getting absolutely *zero* traffic on any of my repos except for days I post about them on Ruqqus. This is not normal, so what could be the cause of it? Did github flag me as spam or something and suppress my repos from discovery channels? I did join less than a month ago and made a lot of contributions right off the bat, so maybe the servers think I'm a bot or something?

On the Ruqqus website itself, usually it's seen as a good thing to give constructive feedback on something. However in the Discord, most people practically worship the admins, and the mods too, and treat them like gods of Ruqqus or something. They're always the center of everything, and you don't dare oppose even one thing they do or else everyone gets in a hivemind and shits all over you for it. This is starting to look like the same kind of cult mentality that AHS has, and I don't think that's healthy for Ruqqus. I think some of the admins and mods are even starting to believe it and now think they're superior to others because of it, and that will undoubtedly lead to power abuse.

Anyone know why the discord users are doing this?
post.body_html:
On the Ruqqus website itself, usually it's seen as a good thing to give constructive feedback on something. However in the Discord, most people practically worship the admins, and the mods too, and treat them like gods of Ruqqus or something. They're always the center of everything, and you don't dare oppose even one thing they do or else everyone gets in a hivemind and shits all over you for it. post.body:
I have a small problem where github is not letting anyone discover any of my repositories naturally. Most people I see get about 10-20 downloads per repo on average after a month or two, and get a small amount of traffic each day. This is typically done without any promotional efforts, so basically through the github algorithm and people discovering it through searching and exploring.

However, only one person other than me has ever downloaded something of mine, and according to the insights I'm getting absolutely *zero* traffic on any of my repos except for days I post about them on Ruqqus. This is not normal, so what could be the cause of it? Did github flag me as spam or something and suppress my repos from discovery channels? I did join less than a month ago and made a lot of contributions right off the bat, so maybe the servers think I'm a bot or something?
